user_text: Keming is hands down the best Chinese place in Hoboken. They offer a pretty extensive menu, from chinese American to traditional Chinese. We ordered the xiaolongbao (little steam porkbuns/soup dumplings), spicy wonton, sesame chicken, and the fatty pork Mala casserole. We really enjoyed the entire meal. The best dish was the fatty pork mala casserole. It's a traditional Chinese dish, dry spices with fatty pork and a bunch of veggies. The second best dish was the sesame chicken. Good chunks of chicken and not just fried breading like you would get elsewhere. The XLB and the spicy wonton were both really good as well, our one criticism is both the wrappers were too thick. The servers were nice, a little rough around the edges but overall great. We ordered a tea that they forgot about it until we were almost done, but in hindsight they probably did us a favor as we were able to finish everything we ordered and then use the tea as palate cleanser. The decoration was interesting but it's now something to be expected of authentic Asian restaurants. The wall by the door had m&ms painted on it and the opposite wall had a mural of traditional chinese men at a banquet. I got a good laugh from this. I'll definitely be back, also it's byob, what more could you ask for.

Ugh.The ordering process is like dealing with the plague.There are literally no online ordering options, which means you have to call.  Which sucks in and of itself.  But what sucks more is that -whatever menu you are referencing- may or may not be relevant.Here are my experiences, and feedback which should be considered: -See it online? "We no longer have that dish!"-See it in a print menu? "We no longer have that dish!"-See it on Yelp?  "We no longer have that dish!"Align yourselves, please, around a single menu, and broadcast accordingly.

this is a new spot in hoboken and you know I have to try all the new spots! I ordered the pork dumplings, lo mein, and general tso's chicken. This is a solid order when checking out a new asian spot ANYWHERE.The dumplings were good but I would rate them a touch gummy. You know when dumplings sometimes overcook the starch gums up and that is what happened.The lo mein wasnt bad but not the best I have had honestly. The meat in the lo meon was very fatty which was not a good sign. Flavor was ok though.Now the star of the show... the general tso chicken... I liked the kick of spice it has and the texture was on point. The chicken flavor did not come through and so I would have to put it in the 3/5 star range.Overall, the delivery was quick and ordering easy but that is typical for any asian spot. The food was a 3 out of 5 star. Would I order again... yes... am I dying to order it again... no

The food is alright here, but I do not think I could consider this place a true Szechaun place as I've had better in Flushing. I had the string beans with salty/crispy meat bits & rice lunch special and majority of what I tasted was white pepper. The redeeming quality to the string beans was that it was crunchy and not mushy. The mapo tofu was not as spicy or flavorful as I hoped it would be, and the three-cups chicken lacked the soy sauce flavors I was expecting it to have, and was almost bland against my taste buds. The cool cucumber appetizer was good and what I expected it to taste like. This place has affordable lunch specials, and they are available on weekends as well, which is nice for the locals in the area.My opinions here are most definitely biased as I've had better in queens, NY. But for the Hoboken area this place is decent.

My friend and I were trying to decide where to dine in the area, when I remembered that I had been meaning to try the recently opened Szechuan restaurant, Keming.  I had grown to love this spicy cuisine over the past few years and was thrilled to see that I could now get it easily in Hoboken.  Despite it being one of the coldest evenings of the winter so far, the restaurant was packed on that Friday evening.  We selected a table away from the door and sat down to menus that were mainly recognizable American Chinese offerings.  However, the back of the menu included "Classic Style"  Szechuan casseroles and other authentic dishes.  Plus, if you really looked closely at the main menu, you would find adventurous ingredients like preserved egg, tripe, rice cakes, and more - rare finds in the neighborhood.We decided to indulge in their spicy offerings by sharing the Thai Hot and Sour Soup and the Dan Dan Noodles in Spicy Sauce.  We were shocked to discover that the soup was served in such a large bowl that splitting it between us was almost enough for a full meal on its own!  The spicy, aromatic broth was a bright red exclamation mark of herbs that packed a kick.  The hearty soup contained chunky vegetables, such as cabbage and tomatoes.   The Dan Dan Noodles had the perfect texture and were served in just enough chili oil to cover the pasta, but could have actually used extra to make it even more robust.  Prior to seeing the large sizes of the starters, we had also decided to split the Chicken with Eggplant and Ma Po Tofu.  The poultry entree had several large pieces of tender chicken, though I would have loved more.  The Japanese eggplant had the perfect consistency without being too mushy.  The Ma Po Tofu was the only dish that I was "eh" on.  I thought it needed more spice and richness; it just seemed rather bland, and the pork could have had more seasoning.  I also wished that they would have offered brown rice, but we were informed that they only had white.Overall, the meal contained obviously quality ingredients, served in a neat presentation and at affordable rates.  Between the friendly owner, bring-your-own beverage capabilities, and the cozy dining room with the "Happy Everything" sign on the wall, Keming created a very homey atmosphere.  I cannot wait to go back for the tripe, hot pot, soup dumplings, and to try more authentic Szechuan plates.  This is truly a welcome addition to the often humdrum Hoboken culinary scene.
Nice Szeuchuan place. The hosts and servers were nice and friendly. The food was awesome.Fried Rice - 4.85/5Soup Dumpling -  4.65/5Fish in Szechuan oil - 4.5/5Overall a good experience !

Very similar to a nyc style take out highly recommend the soup (pork/dumplings ($6.95), wonton with spicy sauce ($5.95)and dan dan noodles ($8.95) for appetizers, love their casseroles ($25.95)and their beef noodle soup (Szechuan, Spicy green peppers & tendon ($12.95). They are open on holidays even on New Year's Eve and they have take out, they take cash or card, parking is available but could be tough to find Thursday- Saturday nights, good luck!

Had to downgrade after the last two experiences here, particularly the meal tonight. Everything was pretty tasteless- particularly the chicken lo mein and egg drop soup. Chicken lo mein smelled heavily of garlic, but otherwise very bland with almost 0 chicken or veggies. On a prior order I tried the won ton soup, this was also very bland. Hoping it was just an off night with the kitchen!

Much better than the average take out, but since they are a dine in restaurant and to be fair, I will compare it to other sit down Chinese restaurants...although there are none in Hoboken.Without mentioning names in comparing Keming to one in JC, one in Wallington and one in Wayne.The food for this type of site down Chinese is just ok.  We've gotten their mala pot (which is just a random mix of whatever is in the kitchen), their beef tendon, xiao long bao, dan dan noodles, and everything was just decent.  The seasonings are good and as authentic as it comes in Hoboken, but it is nothing compared to other Chinese restaurants in NNJ of this caliber.  Their spice level is not true sichuan as they are seriously lacking in the numbing department.For sit down service, it's ok.  The wait staff certainly tries hard to please, but they need to figure out how to run the front house of a restaurant and have wait staff which are "their" tables vs. everyone try your best to service the entire restaurant.If you are looking for better than take-out, this is your place in Hoboken as there is no other sit down Chinese restaurant here.  But if you are looking for true, authentic and mouth water Sichuan or Chinese food, go elsewhere...but you'll definitely need a car lol.

For a 9 o'clock on a Thursday, there were still a good few tables dining. We ordered the soup dumplings and the beef lomein. The soup dumplings taste slightly better than the frozen ones you would buy at a Chinese supermarket. The lomein is also a level better than one you'd order from a typical takeout place. I would say Keming is a good option if you want Chinese, but don't want takeout. It seems pretty authentic for the area. Plus they have a Szechuan hot pot, which I'll be back to try! Tip - BYOB! There's a liquor store right next door (but it's a bit pricy)

Came here last night after my friends recommended it.  For as many restaurants Hoboken has to offer, I can't seem to find a good spot to get chinese food.  This will be my new go-to.I wasn't brave enough to try one of the hot pots, but most of the people around us were ordering them.  We started with the pan fried wontons and dumplings.  The wontons were amazing; I wasn't a big fan of the dumplings but I think that's just a personal preference.  We both went with our typical order of General Tso's chicken which came with white rice.  This was different than your typical fried greasiness that you usually get from chinese takeout restaurants.  The meat in the chicken was all white and tasty.  My boyfriend didn't think it was spicy enough but now we know for next time to ask them to make his spicier.  The service was a little slow, as there was only one server for the entire restaurant but it's BYOB so we used the extra time to finish our wine.  It was very quiet inside but cutely decorated.  It's a step above your typical chinese restaurant.  Would definitely recommend to dine in.

This is the best Sichuan restaurant I have tried in New Jersey, period. I never thought I'd be able to say I'd like a Sichuan restaurant in NJ, but here we are. I tried Kem Restaurant delivery last night and was so pleasantly surprised by how good everything we ordered turned out. We got the Beef Mala Casserole - reminiscent of "dry pot" for those of you fans of Mala Project in Manhattan - which was a seriously delicious sauté of different vegetables, rice cakes, thin fatty beef slices, and tofu. We also ordered the Mouth Watering Chicken 口水鸡, dry fried string beans 干煸四季豆，and the mapo tofu 麻婆豆腐 - all of these dishes were full of flavor and awesomely spicy. I'm really excited to check this restaurant out in person next time to explore more items on the menu - I'll be sure to update my post with more photos and an update once I go!

If there are half stars I'd like to give them a 3.5. Yes they are one of the most authentic Chinese places in town, but somehow it missed hitting the spot for me. I've been here twice and done a take out once, maybe I haven't found the favorite dish yet. For what I can remember -Good - Sesame chicken, solid but a bit too crispy and the meat is not as soft to my liking. But still recommend as I know I'm critical for my Chinese food.Shredded pork with garlic sauce, I like it but a bit too much on the sweet side. Young chow fried rice - good, but again a bit too sweet. A bit disappointing -Ma la pot - this is a very popular Chinese dish and I had high hopes for it. Non authentic Chinese place wouldn't even have  this on the menu. But I think it's over priced for what you get. I was quite surprised for how small that dish was. There were a lot of potatoes to fill in the pot which was also cut too thick for flavor to seep through. The dried tofu is a bit too hard - needs to be cooked down more. The tofu puffs are good. I barely tasted the spice. Not sure if I should've ask them to make it extra spicy but I assumed "ma la" by default should be spicy enough. But in general I like it more than other Chinese restaurants in Hoboken so I will go back and recommend for a try if you haven't been.

I went to this restaurant because I noticed they were new and I was excited to try them out. I ordered beef with peppers which was was not spicy on the menu. I explained to the man at the restaurant that I was unable to eat spicy food due to my stomach and he said, "Don't worry, it won't be spicy" When I brought the meal home I received spicy beef with peppers.It was so spicy I couldn't even eat it. I ordered pan fried wontons and they were deep fried wontons... which were also dry. They didn't even include sauce. I'm sure the food isn't horrible, but this experience left a bad taste in my mouth. I brought the food back and asked for a full refund which they did - However, I was looking forward to lunch not a refund and by that point, lunch was already over. You only have one chance to make a first impression. I will not try them again.
Ordered delivery and it definitely hit the spot. I love salty and spicy food, so the dan dan noodle and sautéed string bean with minced pork was amazing!

I really wanted to like this place because there's no good Chinese spots in Hoboken and the reviews looked pretty solid. We ordered Dan Dan Noodles and Dumplings (soupy). The apps were solid and I thought we were off to a good start. The dan dan noodles I've had a bunch and the flavor was very interesting. For dinner we had Pad Thai and I had the Szechuan style broiled pork that was suppose to be so hot the waiter made several remarks as if to take extreme precaution (LOL). Both entrees were disappointing and my dish was far from spicy. The quality of the ingredients in both appeared to be lacking. We barely ate our entrees. Oh well - the hunt for good Chinese in Hoboken continues ...

Easily the most authentic Chinese food in Hoboken (I lived in China for nearly 3 years, and my wife for nearly 7), which is probably part of the reason for most of the negative reviews.  This isn't the best place to go to if you want General Tso's or chicken and broccoli, but if you're looking for cumin lamb that tastes like it would in Xinjiang, or Sichuan food that's actually made with Sichuan peppercorns, this is the place for you.    The Sichuan selections are the highlight of the menu (the only place in Hoboken you'll find mapo tofu with actual flavor), and their beef noodle soup creates the interesting combination of street flavors of Taipei with Sichuan numbing pepper.  I give them 4 stars instead of 5 because they do have lesser quality in their "standard" American Chinese dishes - they're pretty much standard takeout quality.  So if you're looking for something to compete with Precious or Lo-Fatt Chow, this isn't the place; but if you're looking for authentic mainland flavors, it's the only place in Hoboken that's even trying.

If you haven't had a Mala casserole from Keming, run, don't walk over and order one. It's not a flavor I have had in a long time, not in the US prior to this. Mala laterally means numb and spicy. We ordered the assorted one. It has chicken, beef, lotus roots, tofu sheets, various other things and spam yes Chinese spam in it. And then there is the Mala flavor. No words can do it justice. It's not saucy. It's a combination of chili spicy and Sichuan peppercorns which if you happen to taste one literally gives a temporary numbing sensation on your tongue. Such comfort food on a snowy winter night. The other dishes mini juicy buns etc are decent too.
Good quality and good portion. A must go place if you like Chinese food. Very authentic!!!!!

The wonton dumplings here are delicious ! I've dined at the restaurant itself only once, but this is my go to for ordering in when I crave Chinese. The food has always been consistently great. The delivery is quick and the portions are perfect.

We ordered the xiaolongbao (little steam porkbuns/soup dumplings), spicy wonton, sesame chicken, and the fatty pork Mala casserole. We really enjoyed the entire meal. The best dish was the fatty pork mala casserole. It's a traditional Chinese dish, dry spices with fatty pork and a bunch of veggies. The second best dish was the sesame chicken. Good chunks of chicken and not just fried breading like you would get elsewhere. The XLB and the spicy wonton were both really good as well, our one criticism is both the wrappers were too thick. The servers were nice, a little rough around the edges but overall great. We ordered a tea that they forgot about it until we were almost done, but in hindsight they probably did us a favor as we were able to finish everything we ordered and then use the tea as palate cleanser. The decoration was interesting but it's now something to be expected of authentic Asian restaurants. The wall by the door had m&ms painted on it and the opposite wall had a mural of traditional chinese men at a banquet. I got a good laugh from this. I'll definitely be back, also it's byob, what more could you ask for.

Good quality and good portion. A must go place if you like Chinese food. Very authentic!!!!!

The wonton dumplings here are delicious ! I've dined at the restaurant itself only once, but this is my go to for ordering in when I crave Chinese. The food has always been consistently great. The delivery is quick and the portions are perfect.

My casserole came out in a wooden salad bowl.  Half the food I see in Yelp pics are no longer on the menu.Food tasted good, although most of it was too salty and not szechuam spicy.What's up with the M&Ms busting out of the wall for decor?

Love it. Simply love it. I was casually perusing Yelp looking for soup initially as it was a cold, rainy day in Hoboken and I wasn't in the mood to cook. What caught my attention was that they offered Xiao long bao (soup dumplings, $5.95 for six I think. They have it listed as "Little Juicy Pork Bun") and I was sold! I was also intrigued with the Mala casserole (Fatty beef, $25.95) due to watching too much Food Ranger on YouTube. When I got there around 11:30 AM, there were only about two group of people and plenty of room. I was accommodated and seated immediately. I know, I ate like a starving little piggy but I justified it by telling myself that I don't come and visit very often and I can take leftovers home and eat them for dinner....which I did because that Mala Fatty Beef Casserole was HUGE. It was a mixture of fatty beef (better than it sounds, I promise), napa cabbage, lotus roots, tripe, wood ear mushrooms (I think) and some sort of jelly-like item that I frankly couldn't identify but ate anyway. The vegetables were still crisp and fresh, just how I enjoy them. The beef was excellent in portion. The price is steep but it can feed two people....one me over two meals. The Xiao Long Bao.....best I've ever had in terms of taste. Better than Joe's Shanghai in NYC and Din Tai Fung in LA. IN MY OPINION so don't skewer me. The dumpling dough was on the thick side and wasn't folded correctly on some as on a couple of my dumplings, the dough tore and the soup ran out but the flavor of the soup and meatball was EXCELLENT. If I didn't have the mala casserole, I might have ordered two more Xiao long bao as a full meal. Definitely coming back the next time I'm in Hoboken.

Kind of a strangely decorated place, with inspirational decor, an m&m wall painting and blue ceiling recessed lighting.  Also empty on a Sunday night.  A large family ate in the back, so they can accomodate large groups.  It doesn't seem like they have two person tables.  Weirdly enough, I think they have wifi.  We ordered the pork pan fried wontons, and were told that they're actually deep fried which was fine.  We had originally wanted the pork pan fried dumplings but they said they were out.  We also ordered the famed little juicy pork buns (aka xiao long bao) and both were yummy.  The pan fried dumplings came out hot on a plate with a sweet and sour sauce, and the soup dumplings came out in a covered bamboo steamer.  We had to ask for the soup spoons for the dumplings, which was no big deal. They were pretty goox-- a little doughy but not a huge deal when you soak them in the soupy insides and a bit of vinegar. They also accomodated our requests for extra rice (yay) since we ordered an entree to share (peking style pork rib) which had a lot of bones, a lot of fat, but was pretty tasty with it's hoisin and five spice sauce.So while the place is a teeny bit tacky, the food is good.

It appears that this place is frequented as a sit-down destination by those in the know. Also, when you do see diners inside during early evenings or at lunch, many are Chinese - which is something you might see in New York counterparts, but rarely in any of Hoboken's existing Chinese restaurants.Here are some other items worth trying. For an appetizer, try the shredded beef/pork/chicken w spicy green peppers burrito. They call it a burrito, but that's more of a best guess translation. Its really a pan fried scallion "pancake" wrapped around a delicious mixture of meat and spicy green peppers. As with many of the spicy dishes there, "spicy" is a relative term and more mild than spicy. This appetizer can serve 2, but can be shared among 4 if each takes a portion.  For entrees, try these with white rice: dry sauteed spring beans with minced pork, dry fried shredded beef.  Different, but tasty and worth trying. For more tips, check out my earlier review below.Sometimes, there is only one server, but any wait is worth it. The retail rents are so high in this town that it probably eats a lot of their margin, especially for a place without a liquor license.
One of our most favorite restaurants! Food is delicious, service depends on how busy they are but it's justifiable. Everything from their soups to main course hits the spot. Highly recommend it!

I've been here twice in a week and my husband 4 times. The food is so incredible. Some of the best Chinese and Szechuan food I have ever eaten (including dozens of trips to flushing, manhattan Chinatown, SF, Seattle...) and it's here in Hobo!!!! Lucky us!!! Definitely get the hot pot, the dumplings (soup, pan fried pork, all are amazing). The wonton soup has the most delicate and flavorful wontons I ever ate, and the chicken in spicy sauce is one of the most delicious things period.

We gave this new place a try and we were not disappointed. I honestly can't remember what this was before, but I am glad this took over. The place was a bit empty, but I don't think many know about it yet.I wanted to be adventurous and order the traditional food but I wasn't and got my standard General Tso's chicken and the wife Pad Thai. We started with the pan fried pork dumplings. All of it was absolutely delicious! The dumplings were so good as well as the sauce that went with them. They were hearty and full of flavor, not typical over fried stuff. I asked for my chicken to be extra spicy and they did not slack off, but still maintained great flavor with heat. The chicken looked appetizing and like real chicken, unlike most Chinese places in town. The sauce was delicious. The lady's pad thai was also delicious, and a massive portion. Service was pretty good and they explained the hot pot to us and answered questions. It was a little slower towards the end when we wanted to get the check but that's ok.Overall, this is so far, a much better quick Chinese option in town with what seems like real ingredients and not double fried gunk. We will definitely be back here or at least order delivery.

Could have been four stars if the service wasn't so poor. It's the only seemingly legit Chinese place in Hoboken.Ordered the lil pork bun (or whatever they call the item on the menu). From the name, I expected an actual PORK BUN, like the steamed, white, soft puff kind. In actuality, it's a bamboo steamer with several soup dumplings- if they could be called soup dumplings. The pork is an offputting pink, and the soup isn't so much soup but rather the unwanted juices from the meat. Usually, XLB meat is well put together and obviously cooked. This isn't the usual XLB, I guess. Also, I'm not Chinese so maybe my opinion isn't even valid...Boyfriend got the general tso's chicken and it was really good. I couldn't stop myself from stealing from his plate. Crispy, the sauce was great.The thing is, when we entered, we didn't know what to do. No welcome, no 'please wait to be seated' or even 'sit anywhere.' When we ended up sitting, we didn't get a server for a while. Drink refills (on our waters) were so hard to come by since our server was all over the place; it seems like they need more hands on deck. Also an unusual catch: I tried to order four different things on their menu, and each time, our server told us they weren't serving that particular dish. Why... is... it... there...?

This restaurant has to be the worst dining option in all of New Jersey. If I could give them half a star, I would. We asked if they had their hot pot, and were told that the wire was not long, and only one table could get hot pot. Just downright strange. We still decided to give the place a try and ordered their chicken lo mein, pork short ribs and pork buns. The pork buns were edible. The rest were horrendous! The lo mein (it takes talent to mess up lo mein) had half a bottle of oil and 5 strands of chicken. The pork short ribs had 3 mini morsels that could be chewed among the 10 oily pieces. All in all, the only edible part of the meal was the plain white rice. This restaurant is utter rubbish.

I've been there for three times. Pricey and the food I ordered was too spicy. In the mean time, the service was bad at all. The food was ready for a long time but the waiter didn't notice me. My time was wasted and they were lack of communication. You can see the customers were way less than other Chinese restaurants. Miss the previous Thai restaurant. Second worst Chinese restaurant in Hoboken.
The quality of food here is average and not very consistent. Last time I went one dish was super salty.

Food is authentic but portion is small. Lunch set may not be enough food for guys. In Manhattan you'd get a lot more food with an extra $1. But there's little competition in Hoboken for authentic Chinese food, so they get to set the price. Takeout service is efficient. I called to place the order and it was ready for me in 10 mins.

Better than your run-of-the-mill Chinese food place.  I'm no expert on Chinese but this was solid.  Unfortunately they only had a very limited Thai selection, the menu said otherwise.  However what we go was all better than average.  Looking forward to trying some other dishes at this place.

Consistently great food. The sauce they use in their meals tastes like it comes from the fountain of youth. The lunch specials here are all nicely priced, and the dinner options offer an excessive amount of food most of the time, all while being very good. Nothing here has given me stomach issues unlike every other Chinese restaurant in Hoboken since the food used here seems to be of a much higher quality. Service here is hit or miss as sometimes you are not given much attention except when your food is ready. The candies at the entrance are a nice touch and offer something different. I have tried many items here from the soups to the classic style casseroles and always found it to be better than any other Chinese restaurant in Hoboken by a great amount.
My wife loves hot pot so I was excited to bring her here.  If you want a different type of Chinese food come here and try hot pot.  The chicken teriyaki scallion pancakes are awesome.

I'm Chinese and this place is legit Chinese food. I prefer Cantonese style but they have great food here for other Chinese cuisine. Start you meal with the dumplings especially the XLB soup dumplings. The fried rice is great and lots of spicy dish options. The best vegetable side dish in the town: sautéed green beans with the minced pork. Tender soft green beans and the salty minced pork go great with white rice or anything. I am a meat eater and this dish is my favorite.

* Pan Fried Pork Dumplings - pretty good (but don't put them in sealed container for delivery, because then they become Fried Steamed Dumplings)* Little Juicy Pork Bun - This is NOT a soup dumpling, so don't confuse it, as other reviewers said it is. It's wet pork and doesn't have an appealing flavor* Wonton Soup - Flavorless* Lo Mein - This was the worst dish of all. I literally can't eat it after a few bites of trying. It's a giant plate of over-roasted garlic (and I love garlic!). The noodles are just garnish. I literally had to throw it out.

Placed an order for pick up on a Saturday night--- we wanted to get it delivered but for some reason they weren't offering their delivery service?We ordered: pork fried dumplings, soup dumplings, a wonton soup and the pad Thai with chicken. Wins:  the pork fried dumplings were delicious! And the pad Thai was good but I would have preferred it to be more peanut based. Also the pad Thai had a little kick to it which was fine but not sure if it's for everyone. The wonton soup didn't have much flavor and my husband was pretty disappointed. The soup dumplings were pretty good....but there's potential to improve the flavor. All in all I would come back here for those pork fried dumplings  yum!

I was extremely dissatisfied with the Chinese food in Hoboken until (and boy am I glad) I found Keming! I ordered from here three times this week-- don't judge me! The food is fantastic! You'd be silly to go anywhere else for Chinese food!

A neighborhood gem in Hoboken.  This is real authentic freshly made Chinese food, not the cheap greasy Americanized Panda Express type fast food.  Each time we come here, the restaurant is full of groups of Chinese and other Asian people enjoying huge spreads of delicious food which is a good sign.  The vegetable dishes are my favorite.  Portions are large and ingredients are fresh.  The tofu mushroom dish is a must.  It is full of big fresh juicy meaty mushrooms!   One order feeds me for two meals.  My husband loves the dumplings and wontons which taste freshly made, not frozen.  Decor is simple, casual and the restaurant and bathrooms are very clean.  Real hot sauce and soy sauce are available for the table in ceramic containers, not plastic packets. I believe this is a family run place because the staff takes pride in offering excellent service.

I've gotten food at Keming twice so far, one for hot pot and once for takeout. This place is a gem for their hot pot. You can't get hot pot anywhere else in the area. They give you a choice of soup base (we chose Tom Yum, wasn't too spicy), then you pick a variety of foods you'd like to add to the soup at your leisure. We had six people, and chose the lamb, beef, cabbage, mushrooms, potato, wide vermicelli noodles (go with the thin instead), the shanghai noodles (delic), and maybe one or two other things. It was a large amount of food and we were very full. Next time I'll swap the potato for the rice cakes. We also got a seafood casserole, which is the picture on the menu, and the "juicy pork dumplings," which are soup dumplings, which stacked up pretty well to Joes Shanghai in Chinatown, which has arguably the best in New York. Everything was delicious!!I also got take out beef chow fun, made extra spicy. The noodles were perfectly cooked and full of flavor. Less take out style, closer to something you'd find in a more authentic Chinatown restaurant. I'm highly impressed with Keming and will make it a regular stop in the future.

I really want to like this place. It is the most authentic Chinese restaurant in Hoboken. The taste is good. However it is overpriced and the portion is small. $13 for a small plate of cauliflower is simply too expensive.

Service was great. Incredibly attentive.I got the General Tso's chicken was SO good. Portion was a little small, but the meat quality was incredible. I'll definitely be coming back to try more options...

The food here very delicious. I ordered a mala casseroles seafood one dish enough for two people. This is a Sichuan restaurant where make dumplings and noodles too. It is my first time here, so I will come back to try other dishes too.

This is my initial review. I will definitely try other dishes and update my scores but for now it's 2 stars.  Why?General Tso's chicken- amazing sauce but the execution of the fried chicken pieces is sub par. It's a little undercooked which makes it gooey and way too much dough. I'm disappointed since I trusted a review that says crunchy and delicious. Pork rib with garlic - it's cumin and peppers . I don't mind the peppers but the cumin is so overwhelmingly overpowering the dish. My partner asked me if I think the cumin was accidentally poured on the dish. For a minute I thought I ordered Indian food. The hot and sour soup was ok. I had better and cheaper. Again, I may have ordered the wrong dishes so I will give them another chance. Will keep you posted but for now it's 2 stars !

Made my way here on Sunday evening for dinner with my cousin and was seated right away. We decided to move outside after we realized they didn't have AC :/ the service was quick and the food was hot and tasty. The pork bun soup dumplings were definitely the highlight. We also got the beef and broccoli which was delicious! The only disappointing dish was the dan dan noodles. I often order this fish as Szechuan restaurants and this particular one was only flavored with hot oil. Otherwise I enjoyed the meal and may return here

This is some of the most disappointing Chinese food I've ever had. We ordered for pick up yesterday and had to throw a lot of it out because it was so bland and eat leftovers instead. The wonton soup was in water rather than any sort of chicken broth. The Ma Pa Tofu wasn't very spicy and the sauce was thin watery and had no other flavor. We also ordered DanDan Noodles which was basically spaghetti with very little sauce. Everything had a strange aftertaste. We went there based on the other positive reviews, but frankly I could have had better Chinese food by picking up something frozen from Trader Joe's.

Best Chinese food in Hoboken without a doubt.  I've tried all the other spots, and they're all Chinese-American fusion - nothing really authentic about them.  This spot is the closest to legit Chinese food in the area.I got delivery while at work and ordered the following:Beef Stew Noodle Soup was better than many I've tried in NYC.Soup dumplings were average at best, but the only place in Hoboken that offers them (also getting them delivered instead of fresh out the steam pot doesn't help)Cold Chicken w/ Spicy Sauce was authentic.Going to be ordering from here for Chinese going forward.EDIT: New favorites at Keming:Double Cooked PorkBoiled Sliced Fish Szechuan StyleBraised Beef Tendons Hot Pot(disclaimer: all spicy dishes for you non-spice eaters)
SiChuan style Chinese food in Hoboken. Taste good, though a little bit salty. Come here regularly

Inspired to write my first Yelp review in 7 years after eating here last night!It's been a while since I've had Thai food but this place was delicious! Everything was very fresh and light! The sauces weren't heavy or overwhelming.We got 2 orders of the fatty pork buns, DELICIOUS! And chicken pad Thai was yummy, perfect amount of spice.The restaurant is new so maybe they are working out a few kinks in terms of the pace of the service so be patient, but they were so nice and food was delicious!

Dare I say that this is the first authentic Chinese (Sichuan) restaurant in Hoboken?! They serve both Americanized Chinese food (sesame chicken, beef & broccoli, and so on) as well as Sichuan cuisine. Today was my first time here and I got the mala (mala means numbing hot) casserole with tofu sheet jelly. The cumin gave it a nice kick, but it was not unbearably spicy. My husband liked the dish and he is generally very weary of spice. He also got the xiao long bao, which he also liked a lot. I will definitely be coming back to try the Sichuan style fish & other casseroles. I'm so glad I don't have to travel to Chinatown the next time I'm craving spicy Chinese food!

Their shrimp with vermicelli Malta casseroles ONLY contain shrimp and vermicelli!!! I have no idea why it is called Mala Casseroles if it only contain two item. The most ridiculous thing is it's priced 23.95 before tax for this one dish. I feel like I'm an idiot.

Amazing Food & Great Service! This is AUTHENTIC Chinese food. The real deal. Not your Americanize Chinese. Every dish was phenomenal. Such unique and incredibly tasty flavors! The four of simply raved over every bite. Highly recommend the dumplings steamed or fried were excellent, the casseroles, even the Thai they included on the menu since this was a Thai food location is really well done.  The service is kind courteous and takes great care. You won't be disappointed!!! Cannot recommend it enough! Seriously I have had Chinese food all over the world and even have a close friend from Hong Kong who has taught me some dishes and has cooked for me many times and this is some of the best Chinese I have ever had. Leave you expectations of American Chinese food behind and you will be delighted!

Quite good Chinese place in Hoboken. The Xiaolongbao (called "Little Juicy Pork Bun" on the menu) is as good as any I've had in the US. Skin was a bit thick and would have liked more soup in the dumpling, but again very good. Lo Mein was solid and Pork Belly was absolutely excellent.  It's also BYO and there's a liquor store immediately next door, so very convenient.

This is my favorite Chinese Szechuan in Hoboken. I got introduced to this place through a friend. On a sunny day, we went to this place with our baby. It turned out to be a great experience. We are really happy with the food and service. They are children friendly. They helped turn off the TV for our little baby who is not supposed to watch TV. We ordered chicken with spicy sauce which is a cold dish I like, very fresh; cumin lamb adding spicy (yea we love Szechuan food ); and soup dumplings. They also have Chinese herbal tea in cans, which is supposed to bring down the inner heat after the spicy or hot weather. (This part is very Chinese I know). Anyway, great place, will recommend, will go back.

I have a store opened 3 years ago, i know how important the yelp review is for a new grand openning, totally understand how hard and how they need improvements, which always happened at setup period. so i feel bad to see a not nice review for them at beginning. from my visit today, i just feel very cozy and nice here, and taste chinese type like homemade. we fly from LA and visiting here, it is really hard to find good place to eat as hard for parking in NY or NJ. but lucky i finally made my best choice here. try them if you want REAL chinese food.

Food overall is great.However, I have no idea what is going on at this place. Second Monday in a row that I tried to place an order for pick up. No one answers and it is 12:30pm when they advertise "Open 7 Days a Week" Mon- Sat.: 11:00am - 11:00pm Sun.: 12:00pm - 10:30pm. I finally got an answer today and they said sorry they are not open right now. WHAT!? There's no way this place is going to be successful in Hoboken if they are not open during lunch time. Not sure if this place is just trying to get everything together or what but this is so disappointing to a repeat customer.Also one time we got the lunch special on the weekend. The second time we came in to eat they said no lunch special on the weekend (also doesn't specify one way or the other on the menu). So I honestly think they make up the rules as they go.

This was not the greatest experience.  Maybe they are having an off night but the egg drop soup was flavorless and there was some sort of ingredient in the king pao chicken that coated my mouth with what tasted like 409 cleaner and burned when I drank water.  It was disgusting.  Never going back.

Only authentic Chinese place in Hoboken, and therefore also the best authentic Chinese place in Hoboken. It's pretty good. Xiao Long Bao, Peking style pork ribs, string bean with minced pork, Dan Dan noodles - all good. I think they make the authentic dishes better than the obligatory Americanized dishes..so order the actual Chinese dishes and not general tso's. And don't order pad Thai, it's a Chinese place - if you want pad Thai go to T Thai downtown.

I got dinner takeout from here one night. I believe this is the first Sichuan restaurant in Hoboken. It's a little farther north from where I am, but I'm certainly happy to see the extra diversity in this town. I don't know how often I'll order from here, but certainly an option.

As a Taiwanese-american in Hoboken, I struggle with finding authentic Taiwanese/Chinese food in the area. Most of the time, I drive up to Fort Lee to get my asian food fix, but today my Dad recommended going to Keming with him for lunch. Man... it was so good! We ordered the xiaolongbao (soup dumplings) and they were quite delicious. I doubt there is any other restaurant in Hoboken that will serve these things, let alone well. My dad and I are also avid lovers of spicy food and ordered the beef noodle soup and 2 more Szechuan dishes that were equally as yummy and very authentic. Next time I'm craving Chinese food I'll definitely know where to go!

Highly recommend Keming! BYOB and the food is excellent. Tried a hot pot for the first time, which was an experience itself. The little juicy pork buns are a great appetizer. Looking forward to trying more of the menu next time!

The only good sit-down Chinese place in Hoboken! Soup dumplings are delicious and highly recommended. Many other great dishes as well. I'm sure you can find equal or better in Chinatown or by driving further away, but I'm thankful to finally have some good Chinese food in Hoboken.

The food is good. You won't find this kind of food anywhere else in Hobo and it's BYOB. I docked 2 stars because the service is excruciating. They need to hire more staff. Service is very very slow because the times I've been there, there is only 1 person working the front of the house and trying to do EVERYTHING. Pls get more staff and I would come back.

Always have a great experience when dining in.  The food is fast and fresh.  The Dan Dan noodles, wonton in spicy sauce, and the Chicken with spicy green peppers are favorites.  Definitely, a must try place for Chinese that is set apart from the rest.

If I could give this place a half star I would. I ordered (delivery service) General Tso's chicken, egg drop soup, and fried dumplings.  I specifically asked for brown rice and received white rice instead.  General Tso's chicken usually comes with broccoli and there was literally one piece of broccoli mixed in with the chicken.  The dumplings were the wrong ones and there were no noodles( for the soup) or fortune cookies in the order.  I've never ordered Chinese food without receiving noodles or fortune cookies until now.  The food was average at best and the portion small. The delivery driver took off as I was checking the order in the bag.   All I wanted was a decent Chinese food meal on a rainy Sunday and I'm extremely disappointed,  I'll never order from this establishment again.

The food was outstanding here. This place is underrated and has excellent authentic Asian cuisine. Though I did not order the hotpot, the dishes my family and I had were very good. There are definitely some less-than-best Asian restaurants in this town, yet this was very up to par.
So glad they're here , everything we have tried has been on the money. The Soup dumplings are my favorite .

This place is awesome! Great service, and even better food at a very reasonable price.We travel 40 minutes to come here and eat their sesame chicken, or their chicken and broccoli, or their crispy beef...the list is endless! With an extensive menu, we've only scratched the surface of all the food options. They also have a $7.95 lunch menu, so you can enjoy their food at any time.There's ample seating, and the ambience is nice. If you're looking for the crispiest piece of white meat sesame chicken, this is the place for you! Can't wait for our next dinner.

My friends and I walked in around 6pm, and the restaurant had only one customer there. Despite it being non-busy, the servers were just chit chatting and ignored us for a good five minutes. As soon as we asked for the menu, they got annoyed and rolled their eyes at us. Seriously? I would give 0 stars for service if possible.In addition to that, we had to constantly ask for refills of water. They never came by to ask how the food was or if we needed any refills on water. By the way, the food was maybe a 1 star. Not authentic/spicy enough. At the end of our meal, we wanted to order some dessert. However, the server told us they prioritize take outs instead of the customers within the restaurant, which seems supper odd.Also, they give you a hard time if you want to split the bill with friends (each paying with their own card).Worst experience ever.
Pretty authentic Chinese food. Different from take outs. It's def a good place to hang out and have a good dinner. The food here is amazing, but needa wait for a bit.
This is my favorite Sichuan restaurant!! The chef is an expert of spice!!!Recommendation from Sichuaner~
Unexpectedly delicious. The chicken pad Thai however did come in a sweet & sour sauce so I would specify a peanut sauce the next time. But the food was yummy and it's BYOB!

Great authentic Szechuan cuisine. You can tell their chef/s are legit and they use fresh ingredients. I tried a few items and all were exceptional and quite tasty. I look forward to trying s few other items fro their menu. Probably my fav Chinese restaurant in the area. If you're up for new spin on your fav Chinese food classics, give this place a try!

Was really looking forward to trying this place based on all the great review here on yelp.Waited a good 10 min, no one greeted us; no host, one waiter was taking care of everything. Dirty dishes on the table and no one cleaned them up; phone kept ringing and no one answered.  We walked out of the door. Not a good experience at all.

Visited Hoboken for the heck of it and Keming has some decent reviews. Really enjoyed the Sichuan spicy seafood casserole dish - ingredients very fresh. The other stuff we ordered was good too (also fresh ingredients) but the seafood casserole stood out.  In the future, we would just specifically ask for a heavier dose of the Sichuan spice.

They are a relatively new restaurant in town and took over a thai place. Best chinese food in Hoboken.  Food is fresh and not greasy at all which you expect from takeout usually.  I work late hours and even up to 11pm they deliver quality.  Definitely my goto chinese spot in the Boke
Easily the best Chinese food in Hoboken. Everything is made fresh when you order it, not overly fried or beaten to death like some other places.

My friend recommended this restaurant to me. Environment of this restarrant is not bad. Price is reasonable, but food is not as impressive as i imaged. Some of the food is too salty, but the others are delicious. Overall, this is a good restaurant！

I really love the food here. It's fantastic. I'm excited to have a spot for hot pot and soup dumplings in Hoboken. It would be great to see some service improvements to make though. Small changes could help like keeping carafes of water and menus on the table.

We were super excited to try this place based on all the great reviews,  but quite frankly we were disappointed with the food.  Had the egg rolls,  chicken/mushroom dumplings to start whixh were both great.  The vegetable lo mein was tasty. We ordered the Kung Pao chicken and Lamb with cumin and they were both tasteless, and so so bland.  For a schezuan restaurant, we were expecting flavour and spice.
Went for hot pot lunch today and it was good. We didn't order from regular menu other than the fried pork bun so I have to come back. Service was good!

Amazing is the  assorted casserole. We were four and it was enough with a couple of  Appetizers. Very unusual.great sauce and not your main stream heavy American greasy Chinese.Delicate and unusual fresh flavours.We have also tried the hot pot and the Szechuan beef. Thumbs up for all.

Came on a Sunday night to dine in, 2 people. Both glasses on the table were dirty. Received two replacements which were also dirty. One person waiting on all of the tables. Water was given which was luke warm at best. Took 30 min to receive the appetizers (1 egg drop soup and 1 Juicy Pork Bun order, which are dumplings, not the traditional pork bun you'd be thinking of.) After the apps it took at least another 25 min to receive the entrees (Chicken with broccoli and General Tso's chicken.) Food was not good (how can you mess these two dishes up) and not worth the ridiculous wait and excruciating service for such a simple order (wish I would have listened to the other low reviews first but this place is def rated too high.)  Sincerely disappointed. Spend your hard earned money elsewhere  :(
Excellent authentic Sichuan food! Mapo tofu and dry sautéed string beans were delicious.

So good. So satisfied!The "boiled pork" sounded unappetizing but was fantastic! tender pork and some napa cabbage in a delicious broth...i could drink the liquid (and my brother-ion-law DID!) You might want to order extra rice so you can spoon the broth over it.Dumplings were yummy...steamed chicken and onion and the fried pork. We will definitely order again.
No veg food, all other food- chicken, pork and other things were extremely average. Wouldn't recommend this compared to other restaurants in Hoboken.

Hands down the best Chinese food in Hoboken.. I've been there several times during the past 2 weeks and enjoyed every single dish I tried..The owner is one of the nicest people you can ever meet! Keep it up, Keming!

So overall the food is fairly tasty and I would recommend checking it out.  The fried dumplings are especially good.  But my reasons for the review and only 3 stars are   1) They don't offer or even have in their restaurant spicy Chinese mustard.  I love this stuff especially with egg rolls.   I found this very unusual.    2) Most importantly - NEVER ORDER THE WONTON SOUP.   It's really bland.  You get exactly 3 wontons in a white-ish broth and NOTHING ELSE.  No scallions, shredded pork or even crispy noodles.

Great new addition to uptown Hoboken. They have soup dumplings which they call "juicy pork buns" on the menu. Almost up to par with Dumpling man in the city, but as this is in walking distance from my apartment I'll take it over the hike to NYC any day of the week. Staff is very friendly and accommodating. Food is fresh. Can't wait to come back on a cooler day to try one of the hot pots.Also BYOB, which, as always, is a plus in my book (especially with a liquor store next door).

My husband and I are so happy we finally found a respectable Chinese restaurant with fresh ingredients and authentic flavors.  Before Keming, I would only do Chinese in Chinatown NY but now that this is in town, it's my new go-to!
Excellent service, tasty Asian cuisine and very fair prices. I will definitely be revisiting

I've been here on more than one occasion and I enjoyed my experiences. The food is fantastic. I enjoy the spring rolls and curries here. This is one of my favorite places to get Thai in the neighborhood.

We just tried Keming for delivery. Our small group ordered a scallion pancake, double cooked pork, Peking noodles, szechuan style boiled beef, and Hunan chicken. The person who ordered the double Cooke pork was happy but I thought everything was solidly average except for the szechuan boiled beef, which was much taster than I expected. Great broth. I am definitely planning on ordering again and trying other options.

We tried the chicken and onion dumpling, chicken fried rice, and the shredded beef with green pepper. Everything was fresh and tasted delicious. It's a BYOB. They didn't have the hot pot available when we came so will try it the next time we are here.
We got take out, the food was great and the staff super friendly. As soon as I walked in the place it smelled great. Def our new spot for Chinese food!

Accidentally went in for dinner with our daughter and husband and granddaughter. What a pleasant surprise, food was excellent, authentic, delicious, service was informative and prompt. Loved it. Will go back.

Is it politically incorrect to point out that this is the only Chinese restaurant in town frequented by the area's Chinese population?  We've been here several times.  Each time the food has been excellent.  On two occasions the service was excellent.  On the third I believe they were short-staffed in both the kitchen and on the floor.  Like some other reviewers, I recommend sticking to the "Classic Style" section of the menu as much as possible for authentic Sichuan.  The more standard Chinese restaurant fare is also quite good.
Needs some work if they're going to stay open in this town. Out of a lot and was either too spicy or too bland. They were nice though :/

Some Chinese expat friends took us here and raved about the food.  In particular, they recommended a lamb curry and spicy fish stew.  The lo mein and Chinese broccoli dishes were delicious as well.  Decent ethnic food is hard to find in Hoboken. This is a much welcome addition to the food scene in town.
